channel.title: tastytrade: Market Measures
channel.description: It's not always easy to take the measure of a market, whether you've been trading for a day or a decade. On this segment we look under the hood—options probabilities, volatility, trading strategies, futures, you name it—so your trading mechanics are built to manage more winners.

item.title: 2021 Measured
item.description:
2021 turned out to be quite the year for financial markets. Whether it was the meme-stock mania to start the year, the crypto crashes and rallies throughout the year, or the surge in energy prices, there was some kind of action in the market for everyone.

Let’s take a look at how the markets indices performed this year, how they compare to previous years, and how the year wrapped up for commodities, bonds, and crypto.

item.title: IV Contraction In Single Stocks
item.description:
When trading higher IV underlyings, a contraction in market IV may not mean a big contraction for other underlyings even if the IV is much higher.

This phenomenon of non-correlated IVs actually makes the value of using IV Rank much higher. The difference in IVRs of underlyings can tell you which underlyings had their IVs contract and which ones have not yet contracted.

item.title: Puts in Selloffs
item.description:
We’ve looked at how strangles performed after a selloff since many people tend to be hesitant to sell premium after these moves.

But in recent studies, we’ve seen that selloffs have often been followed by a bounce back up, and this whipsaw can actually negatively impact the call side of the strangle.

What if instead of selling strangles, we sold puts? Join Tom and Tony to find out!

item.title: Where to Take Profits
item.description:
Recently, we looked at comparing various mental stop loss levels to determine the optimal level to exit losing trades. While the differences between the performance of different mental stop loss levels was de minimis, the optimal level was 2x the initial credit.

Now that we have an idea where to exit losing trades, where do we exit winning trades? Join Tom and Tony to find out!

item.title: Opportunity Comes in Selloffs
item.description:
Single down days, or short term selloffs, provide excellent opportunities to sell strangles due to the higher P/L and credit you receive.

Generally, selling strangles after down days saw an increase in average P/Ls for that strangle because rapid IV increases.

item.title: The Weekend Rule
item.description:
The Weekend Rule was coined by Richard Donchian in the 1970s as a rule to determine the price movement seen on Monday and Tuesday. The rule states that if the market closes in new high or low ground on a Friday, it is likely to extend that move on Monday and Tuesday.

Is this true? Or is what occurs the following week totally random?

Join Tom and Tony to find out!

item.title: What is Unit Risk?
item.description: Unit risk is defined as the “unforeseen extreme outlier risk” present when trading many contracts of an undefined risk trade, usually on cheaper underlyings. The reason why this risk exists is due to historical evidence of nearly all extreme outlier moves happening to underlyings that were very low in price to begin with. When selling premium on low priced stocks it is important to limit how many contracts you are selling regardless of the price of the option.

item.title: Where to Set Mental Stop Losses
item.description:
Strangles are one of the most popular strategies used at tastytrade because of their high probability of profit (POP). With this high POP comes large tail risk that could greatly impact the overall success of a portfolio.

The solution to this is to set stop losses when you enter the trade. But at what level do we set stop losses so that we don’t exit a strategy that may turn out to be profitable? Join Tom and Tony to find out!

item.description:
In the equity markets, when volatility is high, correlation nears 1. We’ve done previous studies looking to see if this was the case in crypto markets. 

But does this increase in correlation also occur between equities and cryptos?

How often does this happen?

item.title: Buy the Dip

As fear spreads across the market, many stocks are off their recent highs by 5% or more. Investors are trying to figure out if this is a market correction that was past due or something else. 

Many are looking at this as an opportunity to buy the dip in hopes that the bull run continues. But is there any merit to this mindset? Is buying the dip the right thing to do?

Join Tom and Tony to find out!

item.title: Hedging With Short Delta
item.description:
Whenever we sell premium, the biggest risk tends to lie in the chance of volatility expansion throughout the trade—in other words, actual stock moves being larger than anticipated.  

Generally, when trading stocks (and diversified indexes), these volatility expansions tend to always be accompanied with large down moves in the underlying stock.  

Based on this research, our team has developed a key idea on how to hedge a portfolio of short premium: overall short delta in your portfolio.

item.title: More Bang for Your Bitcoin
item.description:
With Bitcoin remaining the dominant crypto by market cap, it seems that other digital currencies look to Bitcoin for direction. 

If we want to increase our exposure to directional moves in the stock market, we can of course use derivatives. But derivatives are not yet easily accessible in the crypto market. Is it possible to increase exposure to the Bitcoin moves in a market where you can only go long?

item.title: How Outliers Affect IV Pops
item.description:
During outlier market days, what happens to volatility in terms of magnitude of expansion?

When trading products that are affected by implied volatility (like options), the key variable to keep track of is exposure to outlier losses. We know short options generally turn a profit until an outlier happens because IV contracts on average, and short premium trades tend to have high POPs.

However, since outliers are bound to happen and their size tends to be unpredictable, keeping exposure small to begin with is the only practical defense to keep a portfolio solvent.
